body:
Hard to explain without digging into Linguistics\*, but: a call for action is more than just a discourse, it's a discourse plus an embedded action. At least in theory you can legislate over that embedded action without legislating against the discourse.

Plus there's another issue - "don't do anything USA considers illegal" is necessary to ensure the site's own survival. Even if this means "follow the censorship embedded in USA law", the result is less censorship than the lack of a platform.

\*I can expand on that though, but I'm talking about performative utterances.

body: A concern I have about that is how to distinguish when individuals can act against immoral, unprotected speech. The government has a due process to help avoid wrongly convicting suspects, but instances of preventing or retaliating against such speech are often considered wrong or illegal when they shouldn't be. On Ruqqus, the administrators are being criticized for banning people even though those people did deserve to be banned based on the information that I have seen. In real life, sometimes people kill or assault to protect themselves from individuals who pose real threats, but they themselves are punished under the law. Is there a better perspective wherefrom to view this issue, or a better solution?

parent.body:
Hard to explain without digging into Linguistics\*, but: a call for action is more than just a discourse, it's a discourse plus an embedded action. At least in theory you can legislate over that embedded action without legislating against the discourse.

Plus there's another issue - "don't do anything USA considers illegal" is necessary to ensure the site's own survival. Even if this means "follow the censorship embedded in USA law", the result is less censorship than the lack of a platform.

\*I can expand on that though, but I'm talking about performative utterances.

body:
IMO people shouldn't be allowed to prevent others from voicing *immoral* speech, so I think any act against the speech *itself* is illegitimate. It's another can of worms if the speech is being imposed upon you - but then the issue is not the speech, it's the imposition.

*Illegal speech* is another can of worms. In Ruqqus the best that can be done is to flag the content so the admins report it to authorities, and let them deal with it. On a government level\* it's trickier, but I think it boils down to "fight speech with speech, fight acts with acts". Anyone using non-speech acts to fight speech is IMO in the wrong.

So for example:

* Alice says "Blacks are bad!" (only speech). Bob throws a stone at Alice for saying that. *What Bob did should be considered illegal.*
* Alice says "Charlie, let's kill that black over there!". (speech *plus* a performative act, a call to action). Bob throws a stone at Alice, to prevent her from killing a black person. *What Bob did should be considered legal.*

Sorry if this sounds extremely vague; it is, kinda. The subject is way more complex than it looks like.

post.title: Voat 5 years ago vs. 15 days ago

body:
I'm almost sure I'm calling "speech" something far more restrict than what you are calling, and that's why we're disagreeing. Just to make sure: for me speech is the content of the message, the discourse itself; usually a descriptive or opinative statement.

>Do you think that all verbal bullying is imposed speech

*All*? Probably. *Most*? Yes. 

And more importantly, bullying is always *engagement*, thus more akin to behaviour than to speech - even if it might *contain* speech.

Let me give you an example. Alice chases Bob around the school to tell him "Bob, your mom is fat!" over and over. The discourse = speech is Alice's message (there's a being out there referred as "Bob's mom" and that being is considerably overweight); the bullying is not the discourse but the engagement itself, Alice chasing Bob to tell him over and over something he doesn't want to hear. 

Note insults are often not speech either; it's harder to draw the line in this case, but they're mostly performative acts - when you're insulting someone you're trying to provoke a reaction, not to voice a descriptive or opinative statement.

>If so, how do you distinguish imposed speech from unimposed speech?

It depends a lot on the situation, but in general: imposed speech contradicts the hearer's *explicit* desire to not hear it. In my Alice and Bob's example, once Bob says "Alice, leave me alone", any further engagement from Alice's part would be already imposed speech.

Another example would be porn in Ruqqus. A lot of people consider porn immoral, so they avoid it; someone actively mislabelling porn content as SFW is trying to impose porn to people who don't want to see it, so it's imposed.

body:
I think you're right: the meaning of "speech" that you're referring to is much narrower than the one I'm referring to. However, mine was informed by many other free speech advocates, who seem to consider a wide variety of behavior as speech.

It seems that you consider pornography as speech as well, but pornography seems much more akin to the "performative acts" that you identify and intended to elicit certain non-rational responses. Same thing with acting, singing, and most protesting, even peaceful—with your restrictive definition of "speech," these would seem unprotected under the principle of free speech, because while speech may be contained therein, these are not exclusively speech. Perhaps there is a more practical moral metaphysics for this issue?

Thanks for sharing so much of your insights about this, by the way.

parent.body:
I'm almost sure I'm calling "speech" something far more restrict than what you are calling, and that's why we're disagreeing. Just to make sure: for me speech is the content of the message, the discourse itself; usually a descriptive or opinative statement.

>Do you think that all verbal bullying is imposed speech

*All*? Probably. *Most*? Yes. 

And more importantly, bullying is always *engagement*, thus more akin to behaviour than to speech - even if it might *contain* speech.

Let me give you an example. Alice chases Bob around the school to tell him "Bob, your mom is fat!" over and over. The discourse = speech is Alice's message (there's a being out there referred as "Bob's mom" and that being is considerably overweight); the bullying is not the discourse but the engagement itself, Alice chasing Bob to tell him over and over something he doesn't want to hear. 

Note insults are often not speech either; it's harder to draw the line in this case, but they're mostly performative acts - when you're insulting someone you're trying to provoke a reaction, not to voice a descriptive or opinative statement.

>If so, how do you distinguish imposed speech from unimposed speech?

It depends a lot on the situation, but in general: imposed speech contradicts the hearer's *explicit* desire to not hear it. In my Alice and Bob's example, once Bob says "Alice, leave me alone", any further engagement from Alice's part would be already imposed speech.

Another example would be porn in Ruqqus. A lot of people consider porn immoral, so they avoid it; someone actively mislabelling porn content as SFW is trying to impose porn to people who don't want to see it, so it's imposed.

body:
Mine is loosely based on Pragmatics from Linguistics; I'm splitting Austin's speech acts and saying the locutionary act itself is speech, while the illocutionary and perlocutionary acts aren't.

>these would seem unprotected under the principle of free speech

Yup, that's correct. To allow singing, acting, peaceful protests, and porn, you need *additional* freedoms, since free speech alone would only cover the content and your ability to share\* it, but not the performance. You need free artistic expression, free association and sexual freedom respectively.

>pornography seems much more akin to the "performative acts" that you identify and intended to elicit certain non-rational responses

The production is a performative act, where the porn actors engage themselves *and the viewer* sexually. That's why (for example) child porn can be banned without hurting free speech - because the performance itself is illegal, and necessary for the speech. (Lolicon is another can of worms. I don't like it but I don't think it should be banned, since it doesn't depend on an illegal performance.)

\*About sharing: here free speech might conflict with certain authorship rights. Personally I think free speech is more important in this regard (as in: screw copyright), but I don't think people are necessarily against free speech if they think "no, copyright is more important in this case".

>Thanks for sharing so much of your insights about this, by the way.

You're welcome! And thank you for contradicting me in a respectful way! I like discussing those things.
